### getEstimatedVLFor() {#a507ceec83cdf219d1598255c3aaa791b}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>unsigned RISCVTTIImpl::getEstimatedVLFor (<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/vectortype">VectorType</a> &#42; Ty)</>}>
This function returns an estimate for VL to be used in VL based terms of the cost model.

For fixed length vectors, this is simply the vector length. For scalable vectors, we return results consistent with getVScaleForTuning under the assumption that clients are also using that when comparing costs between scalar and vector representation. This does unfortunately mean that we can both undershoot and overshot the true cost significantly if getVScaleForTuning is wildly off for the actual target hardware.

Declaration at line <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/riscv/riscvtargettransforminfo-h/#l00049">49</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/riscv/riscvtargettransforminfo-h">RISCVTargetTransformInfo.h</a>, definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/riscv/riscvtargettransforminfo-cpp/#l01448">1448</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/riscv/riscvtargettransforminfo-cpp">RISCVTargetTransformInfo.cpp</a>.

<SectionDefinition>

## EVL Support for predicated vectorization.


Whether the target supports the evl parameter of VP intrinsic efficiently in hardware, for the given opcode and type/alignment.

(see LLVM Language Reference - &quot;Vector Predication Intrinsics&quot;, <a href="https://llvm.org/docs/LangRef.html#vector-predication-intrinsics">https://llvm.org/docs/LangRef.html#vector-predication-intrinsics</a> and &quot;IR-level VP intrinsics&quot;, <a href="https://llvm.org/docs/Proposals/VectorPredication.html#ir-level-vp-intrinsics">https://llvm.org/docs/Proposals/VectorPredication.html#ir-level-vp-intrinsics</a>). 
<ParametersList title="Parameters">
<ParametersListItem name="Opcode">the opcode of the instruction checked for predicated version support.</ParametersListItem>
<ParametersListItem name="DataType">the type of the instruction with the <code>Opcode</code> checked for prediction support.</ParametersListItem>
<ParametersListItem name="Alignment">the alignment for memory access operation checked for predicated version support.</ParametersListItem>
</ParametersList>

### shouldConsiderAddressTypePromotion {#a87303462e710ef447ed4768ea29b3090}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>bool RISCVTTIImpl::shouldConsiderAddressTypePromotion (<a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/aarch64/aarch64promoteconstant-cpp/#a90f8350fecae261c25be85d38b451bff">const</a> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/instruction">Instruction</a> &amp; I, bool &amp; AllowPromotionWithoutCommonHeader)</>}>
See if <code>I</code> should be considered for address type promotion.

We check if <code>I</code> is a sext with right type and used in memory accesses. If it used in a &quot;complex&quot; getelementptr, we allow it to be promoted without finding other sext instructions that sign extended the same initial value. A getelementptr is considered as &quot;complex&quot; if it has more than 2 operands.

Declaration at line <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/riscv/riscvtargettransforminfo-h/#l00426">426</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/riscv/riscvtargettransforminfo-h">RISCVTargetTransformInfo.h</a>, definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/riscv/riscvtargettransforminfo-cpp/#l02450">2450</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/riscv/riscvtargettransforminfo-cpp">RISCVTargetTransformInfo.cpp</a>.
</MemberDefinition>
